title-group.article-title: A neurofuzzy controller for full vehicle active suspension systems

article-meta.aff: School of Engineering and Design, University of Sussex, Falmer, UK

author-notes.corresp: AA Aldair, School of Engineering and Design, University of Sussex, Falmer, East Sussex, BN1 9QT, UK Email: aa386@sussex.ac.uk

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: The main objectives of designing the controller for vehicle suspension systems are to reduce the discomfort sensed by passengers that arises from road roughness and to increase the road handling associated with the pitching and rolling movements. This necessitates a very fast and accurate controller to meet as many control objectives as possible. This paper deals with an artificial intelligent neurofuzzy (NF) technique to design a robust controller. The advantage of this controller is that it can handle the nonlinearities faster than other conventional controllers. The approach of the proposed controller is to minimize the vibration on each corner of the vehicle by supplying control forces to the suspension system when travelling on a rough road. The other purpose of using the NF controller for the vehicle model is to reduce the body inclinations that are made during intensive maneuvers, including braking and cornering. A full vehicle nonlinear active suspension system is introduced and tested. The robustness of the proposed controller is being assessed by comparison with an optimal proportional-integral-derivative (PID) controller. The results show that the intelligent NF controller has improved the dynamic response measured by decreasing the cost function.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: In recent years, several models and controllers have been developed in attempts to improve the riding and handling qualities for modern vehicles. Due to additional mathematical complexity in the suspension system with an active control, most researchers approximate the active suspension system as a linear one when designing the suspension controller. Some researchers have designed a linear controller for a quarter or half vehicle (Kuo and Li, 1999; Smith and Walker, 2000; Feng and Yu, 2003; He and Mcphee, 2005; Biglarbegian et al., 2007; Kumar, 2007; Sung et al., 2007; Biglarbegian et al., 2008; Yue et al., 2008). In all of those publications, a limitation is obvious in that a quarter or half vehicle linear model used to design the control system. It can only indicate the vehicle body vertical movement plus the pitching movement and does not include the rolling movement of the vehicle body.

There are several researchers who have made progress by using a full vehicle model to design the control system to take into account the rolling movement. Gaspar et al. (2003) have used a robust controller for a full vehicle linear active suspension system using the mixed parameter synthesis. A sliding mode technique is designed for a linear full vehicle active suspension system (Chamseddine et al., 2006). A method is developed for the purpose of sensor fault diagnosis and accommodation. March and Shim (2006) present the development of an integrated control system of active front steering and normal force control using fuzzy reasoning to enhance the full vehicle model handling performance. A fuzzy logic-based fast gain scheduling controller is proposed for controlling nonlinear suspension systems for the full car system (Lee et al., 1998).

In fact, nonlinearity inherently exists in damper and spring models (Dixon, 1999; Joo et al., 2000; Li et al., 2004); therefore, the nonlinear effect should be inevitably taken into account to design the controller for practical active suspension system. Tahboub (2005) presented a control method applied to a quarter vehicle model with nonlinear suspension dynamics. In Renn and Wu (2007), two control schemes are designed for the quarter vehicle nonlinear active suspension system to improve riding comfort and to achieve control performance. Feng and Yu (2003) designed a new control strategy for the half vehicle nonlinear active suspension system by using a combined control scheme. A genetic algorithm-based self-tuning proportional-integral-derivative (PID) controller and a fuzzy logic controller are used in two loops. Wn et al. (2004) designed an optimal fuzzy controller for the half vehicle nonlinear active suspension system based on the Takagi–Sugeno (T-S) fuzzy control system.

In this paper, a novel neurofuzzy (NF) controller for full vehicle nonlinear active suspension systems will be developed. The full vehicle model will be investigated to take into account the three motions of the vehicle: vertical movement at the center of gravity, pitching movement and rolling movement.

A NF model combines the features of a neural network and a fuzzy logic model. A large class of NF approaches utilizes the neural network learning algorithms to determine parameters of the fuzzy logic system (Isik and Farrokhi, 1997). The NF system is more efficient and more powerful than either the neural network or fuzzy logic system (Brown and Harris, 1994), which have been widely used in control systems, pattern recognition, medicine, expert system, etc. (Zhang and Kandel, 1998).

In this paper an optimal PID controller will be designed for full vehicle nonlinear active suspension system using the Evolutionary Algorithm (EA). The data obtained from the optimal PID controller are used as reference to design the NF controller. The learning ability of the neural network has been used to tune the parameters of the membership function of the Fuzzy Inference Systems (FISs). The performance of the NF controller has been improved by adding the gain inputs. The Adaptive Response Surface (ARS) algorithm will be used to select the optimal values of the gain inputs. The results of the proposed controller will be compared with that of the optimal PID controller. Six types of disturbances will be investigated to establish the robustness of the proposed controller. The results will show whether the proposed controller is more robust than the optimal PID controller.

sec.title: 2. Neurofuzzy structure
sec.p: Artificial neural networks are good at recognizing patterns. However, they are not good at explaining how they reach their decisions. Fuzzy logic systems, which can reason with imprecise information, are good at explaining their decisions but they cannot automatically acquire the rules used to make those decisions. Those limitations have been a central driving force behind the creation of intelligent hybrid systems, where two or more techniques are combined in a manner that overcomes the limitations of the individual techniques. The NF system is a good example for such a hybrid system. The neuro-adaptive learning techniques provide a method for the fuzzy modeling procedure to learn information about a data set. This technique gives the fuzzy logic capability to compute the membership function parameters that best allow the associated FIS to track the given input and output data. In order to process fuzzy rules by neural networks, it is necessary to modify the standard neural network structure accordingly.

The NF model structure is show in Figure 1 (Tsoukalas and Uhrig, 1997). In this figure, pj is the jth input to the NF network and S is the number of rules. The ith rule of the NF can be described as Ri k: If p1 q is Ai1 q and p2 q is Ai2 q… pn q then Γi q=ζi qBi q, where ζi q=Ai1 q(p1 q)Ai2 q(p2 q)…Ani q(pn q)∑i=1 SAi1 q(p1 q)Ai2 q(p2 q)…Ain q(pn q), Bi q=c1ip1 q+c2ip2 q+…+cnipn q+c(n+1)i; Aij is the ith the membership function of the jth input; q is the qth data for each input (q = 1,2, … ,Q). Every node in layer three is labeled ||, means the inputs of this node have been normalized. Figure 1.
Neurofuzzy structure.
There are different types of membership functions that can be used in NF networks, such as the triangular function, Gaussian function, sigmoid function, generalized bell, etc.
If a Gaussian function is used as the membership function, the function Aij can be described as Aij(pj)=exp(-12(pj-γijσ)2).
The final output of the NF network for the kth data can be written as (1)y*k=∑i=1 SΓi k.

sec.title: 2.1. Neurofuzzy learning algorithm
sec.p: The neural networks are used to tune the parameters of the membership functions of fuzzy systems that are employed as decision-making systems for controlling equipment. Given a training set of input and output data: {(p1 1,p2 1,…,pn 1,y1),…,(p1 Q,p2 Q,…,pn Q,yQ)}. To force the NF system to generate the same outputs of training data when the same inputs are applied to the NF system, the optimal NF parameters (c1i,c2i, … ,cni, c(n+1)i,αij and γij) should be selected for all NF rules. The back-propagation learning algorithm is used to minimize the performance measure of the qth training pair: (2)ψq=0.5(y*q-yq)2.

The NF parameter can be updated as follows: (3)cri(τ+1)=cri(τ)-φ∂ψ∂criγij(τ+1)=γij(τ)-φ∂ψ∂γijσij(τ+1)=σij(τ)-φ∂ψ∂σij, where r = 1,2, … .,n + 1, φ is the learning constant and τ indexes the number of iterations.

Based on this assumption, the rules of the NF network can be written as follows: R1 q: If p1 q is A11 q and p2 q is A12 q then Γ1 q=ζ1 qB1 qR2 q: If p1 q is A21 q and p2 q is A22 q then Γ2 q=ζ2 qB2 q, where ζ1 q=A11 q( p1 q)A12 q( p2 q)A11 q( p1 q)A12 q( p2 q)+A21 q( p1 q)A22 q( p2 q)ζ2 q=A21 q( p1 q)A22 q( p2 q)A11 q( p1 q)A12 q( p2 q)+A21 q( p1 q)A22 q( p2 q)B1 q=c11p1 q+c12p2 q+c13B2 q=c21p1 q+c22p2 q+c23A11 q=exp(-(p1 q-γ11)22σ11 2) A12 q=exp(-(p1 q-γ12)22σ12 2)A21 q=exp(-(p1 q-γ21)22σ21 2)A22 q=exp(-(p1 q-γ22)22σ22 2).
From the above equations, there are 14 parameters that must be updated to train a NF system, depending on the set of training data that are given.

From Equations (2) and (3), the update equations can be obtained as c11(τ+1)=c11(τ)-φ(y*q-yq)∂y*q∂c11, where yq is the desired output: y*q=A11 q(p1 q)A12 q(p2 q)(c11p1 q+c12p1 q+c13)A11 q(p1 q)A12 q(p2 q)+A21 q(p1 q)A22 q(p2 q) +A21 q(p1 q)A22 q(p2 q)(c21p1 q+c22p1 q+c23)A11 q(p1 q)A12 q(p2 q)+A21 q(p1 q)A22 q(p2 q).
Then the update equation of the c11(τ+1) can be written as c11(τ+1)=c11(τ)-φ(y*q-yq) ×A11 q(p1 q)A12 q(p2 q)p1 qA11 q(p1 q)A12 q(p2 q)+A21 q(p1 q)A22 q(p2 q).

In general, for any number of rules and inputs, the update equation of parameter civ can be given as (i = 1,2, … ,S and v = 1,2, … ,n + 1): (4)civ(τ+1)=civ(τ)-φ(y*q-yq) ×Ai1 q( p1 q)…Ain q( pn q) pv q∑i=1 SAi1 q( p1 q)Ai2 q( p1 q)…Ain q( pn q).

The update equation of shape parameters of the membership functions (Gaussian functions) can be written as α11(τ+1)=α11(τ)-ϕ(y*q-yq) ×( p1 q-γ11)A12 q( p2 q)B1 q(σ11 2)(A11 q( p1 q)A12 q( p2 q)+A21 q( p1 q)A22 q( p2 q)) σ11(τ+1)=σ11(τ)-ϕ(y*q-yq) ×(p1 q-γ11)2A12 q(p2 q)B1 q(σ11 3)(A11 q(p1 q)A12 q(p2 q)+A21 q(p1 q)A22 q(p22 q)).

In general, the update equation for the shape parameters (γijandσij) for any number of rules and inputs can be written as (5)γij(τ+1)=γij(τ)-ϕ(y*q-yq) ×(pj q-γij)Πϑ=1 nAiϑ q(pϑ q)Bi q(σij 2)∑i=1 S(Ai1 q(p1 q)Ai2 q(p2 q)…Ain q(pn q)) (6)σij(τ+1)=σij(τ)-ϕ(y*q-yq) ×(pj q-γij)2Πϑ=1 nAiϑ q(pϑ q)Bi q(σij 3)∑i=1 S(Ai1 q(p1 q)Ai2 q(p2 q)…Ain q(pn q)) for ϑ≠j.

sec.title: 3. Design of the neurofuzzy controller
sec.p:
The NF controller is a combination of a fuzzy logic controller and a neural network, which makes the controller self-tuning and adaptive. Figure 2 depicts the NF controller structure. To find the optimal values of the NF parameters for driving the plant to meet all of the control objectives, an optimal PID controller should be designed. The input and output data that are obtained from the optimal PID controller should be used to train the parameters of the NF controller. Figure 2.
Neurofuzzy controller.

The Field Programmable Gate Array (FPGA) is suitable for fast implementation and quick hardware verification. The systems based on it are flexible and can be reprogrammed an unlimited number of times. The rapid evaluation of silicon technologies has helped to reduce the size of FPGA integrated circuits and cost; therefore, the FPGAs can be used as final solutions to implemented many systems. The hardware implementation of the NF controller using the FPGA is explained by the authors (Aldair and Wang, 2011).

sec.title: 3.1. Design of the optimal PID controller
sec.p:
In this paper, the EA has been used to tune the parameters of PID controller. Figure 3 depicts the structure of the multi-population EA. Figure 3.
Structure of a population evolution algorithm.

At the beginning of the computation, a number of individuals (PID parameters) are randomly initialized within a reliable range. The first (initial) generation is produced. If the optimization criteria are not met, the creation of a new generation starts. Individuals are selected according to their fitness for the production of offspring. The parents are recombined to produce offspring. All offspring will be mutated with a certain probability. The fitness of the offspring is then computed. The offspring are inserted into the population, replacing the parents and producing a new generation. This cycle is performed until the optimization criteria are met. The objectives of selecting optimal values of PID are to resolve the inherent conflict between riding comfort and road handling. Therefore, the PID parameters should be selected to minimize the following cost function, which represents the level of total displacements: (7)J=0.5∑μ=1 4ξμ 2, where ξµ is the plant outputs that should be minimized.

The equations of the force control inputs are (8)fμ=-(rpμξμ+riμ∫ξμ+rdμξμ)μ=1,2,3,4, where rpμ,riμandrdμ are the optimal parameters of the PID controller and fµ is the control output signals of the optimal PID controller.

sec.title: 3.2. Training the parameters of the NF controller
sec.p:
After the optimal parameters of the PID controller are obtained, the input and output data of the PID controller will be used to train the parameters of the NF controller using the back-propagation algorithm. Figure 4 depicts the training phase of the NF controller. Figure 4.
Training phase of neurofuzzy.

The bold line means multiple input or output signals. After the optimal NF values are obtained, the NF controller design should be improve by adjusting the gain inputs (GE and GED); as shown in Figure 2, the optimal values of GE and GED can be obtained by using the ARS algorithm. Nguyen (1992) and Sahraian and Kodiyalam (2000) give more detail about this algorithm.

sec.title: 4. Full vehicle nonlinear active suspension model
sec.p:
To investigate the problem of balancing riding comfort and road handling, the four-wheel nonlinear active suspension system with eight dampers is introduced. As shown in Figure 5, the tires are simulated as springs with a constant stiffness ki (i = 1, 2, 3 and 4) and damper with a constant damping ci. The road profile inputs ui excite the tires at each corner and any other mechanical components attached to it. The mass of the components under the suspension system is called unsprung mass mi, while the mass of the components above the suspension are called sprung mass M. the suspension system is composed of a spring with a constant stiffness Ki and a damper with a constant damping Ci. The active suspension forces fi are applied between the sprung mass and unsprung mass to minimize: the vertical motion sensed by passenger when traveling on rough roads and vehicle body motions that are made during maneuvers such as breaking (α) and bending (η). Figure 5.
Full vehicle nonlinear active suspension system.
The vehicle body is represented by a plate of mass M. The suspension points P1, P2 and P4 satisfy the plane equation: (9)|x-x1y-y1z-z1x2-x1y2-y1z2-z1x4-x1y4-y1z4-z1|=0.
Any points on the rigid plate satisfy (10)z=(z4-z1)Lx+(z2-z1)by+z1.
The vertical displacement of center of gravity zc can be calculated from this equation: (11)zc=az1+0.5z2+l1Lz4, where a=0.5-l1L.
Therefore, the displacement at point P3 can be calculated from this equation: (12)z3=-z1+z2+z4.
The pitch angle and the roll angle can be calculated from these equations: (13)α=∂z∂y=z4-z1L (14)η=∂z∂x=z2-z1b.

Ando and Suzuki (1996) proposed the following nonlinear model for the spring and damper forces: Fk=Ki(zi-wi)+λKi(zi-wi)3Fc=Ci(zi-wi)+λCi(z·i-w·i)2sgn(z·i-w·i), where λ is the empirical parameter via testing.

The equations of motion for the system can be written as follows: (15)Maz··1+12Mz··2+l1Lz··4+(C1-C3)z·1+(C2-C3)z·2 +(C3+C4)z·4-C1w·1-C2w·2-C3w·3-C4w·4 +λC1(z·1-w·1)2sgn(z·1-w·1)+λC2(z·2-w·2)2sgn(z·2-w·2) +λC4(z·4-w·4)2sgn(z·4-w·4) +λC3((-z·1+z·2-z·4)-w·3)2sgn((-z·1+z·2+z·4)-w·3) +(K1-K3)z1+(K2+K3)z2+(K3+K4)z4-K1w1 -K2w2-K3w3-K4w4+λK1(z1-w1)3+λK2(z2-w2)3 +λK4(z4-w4)3+λK3((-z1+z2+z4)-w1)3 =f1+f2+f3+f4 (16)-Jxbz··1+Jxbz··2-(C1+C3)b2z·1+(C1+C3)b2z·2 +(C3-C4)b2z·4+C1b2w·1-C2b2w·2-C3b2w·3+C4b2w·4 -λC1(z·1-w·1)2sgn(z·1-w·1)b2 +λC2(z·2-w·2)2sgn(z·2-w·2)b2 -λC4(z·4-w·4)2sgn(z·4-w·4)b2 +λC3((-z·1+z·2+z·4)-w·3)2sgn((-z·1+z·2+z·4)-w·3)b2 -(K1+K3)b2z1+(K2+K3)b2z2+(K3-K4)b2z4 +K1b2w1-K2b2w2-K3b2w3-λK1(z1-w1)3b2 +λK2(z2-w2)3b2-λK4(z4-w4)3b2 +λK3((-z1+z2+z4)-w3)3+K4b2w4 =-(f1+f4)b2+(f2+f3)b2+Tx (17)-JyLz··1-JyLz··4+(C1l1+C3l2)z·1+(C2l1+C2l2)z·2 -(C3l2+C4l2)z·4-C1l1w·1-C2l1w·2+C3l2w·3 +C4l2w·4 +λC1(z·1-w·1)2sgn(z·1-w·1)l1 +λC2(z·1-w·2)2sgn(z·2-w·2)l1 -λC4(z·4-w·4)2sgn(z·4-w·4)l2 -λC3((-z·1+z·2+z·4)-w·3)2sgn((-z·1+z·2+z·4) -w·1)l1 +(K1l1+K3l2)z1+(K2l1-K3l2)z2 -(K3l2+K4l2)z4-K1l1w1 -K2l1w2+K3l2w3+K4l2w4+λK1(z1-w1)3l1 -λK2(z2-w2)3l1 -λK4(z4-w4)3l2-λK3((-z1+z2+z4)-w3)3l2 =(f1+f2)l1-(f3+f4)l2+Ty (18)m1w··1-C1z·1+C1w·1-K1z1+(K1+k1)w1 -λK1(z1-w1)3 -λC1(z·1-w·1)2sgn(z·1-w·1)=c1u·1+k1u1-f1 (19)m2w··2-C2z·2+C2w·2-K2z2+(K2+k2)w2 -λK2(z2-w2)3 -λC2(z·2-w·2)2sgn(z·2-w·2) =c2u·2+k2u2-f2 (20)m3w··3-C3z·3+C3w·3-K3z3+(K3+k3)w3-λK3((-z1+z2+z4)-w3)3-λC3((-z·1+z·2+z·4)-w·3)2sgn((-z·1+z·2+z·4)-w·3)=c3u·3+k3u3-f3 (21)m4w··4-C4z·4+C4w·4-K4z4+(K4+k4)w4 -λK4(z4-w4)3-λC4(z·4-w·4)2sgn(z·4-w·4) =c4u·4+k4u4-f4, where f1, f2, f3 and f4 are the control forces; u1, u2, u3 and u4 are the profile road inputs; JyandJx are the moments of inertia about the y-direction and x-direction, respectively; Tx and Ty are cornering torque and braking torque, respectively, caused by inertia forces.
Equation (22) can be written in state-space form as {Z··}=-[M]-1[K]{Z}-[M]-1[C]{Z·}-[M]-1[N]{S} +[M]-1[G]{F}.
Let state variables {Z1}={Z} and {Z2}={Z·}: {Z·1Z·2}=[0I-M-1K-M-1C]{Z1Z2}+[0M-1G]{F}⌊0-M-1N⌋{S}.

sec.title: 5. Simulations and results
sec.p:
For the full vehicle nonlinear active suspension system discussed in Section 4, Table 1 shows the typical parameters for the suspension model that are used in this study. To design the NF controller, the optimal parameters of the PID controller should be obtained first by using the EA. Then, the input and output data obtained from the PID controller will be used to design the NF controller. Figures 6–8 show the changing of the PID controller parameters with respect to optimization steps. Table 2 shows the optimal values of rpµ, riµ and rdµ. Figure 9 shows the response of the cost function, which is described in Equation (7), with respect to the optimization steps. This figure shows that after 250 iterations, the final value of performance measure reached a negligible value. During the optimization phase, it is assumed that the inputs to the full vehicle model are just the road uneven excitation and control forces. The white noise input is supplied as the road profile. Figure 6.
Changing value of rp during optimization steps. Figure 7.
Changing value of ri during optimization steps. Figure 8.
Changing value of rd during optimization steps. Figure 9.
Performance measurement during optimization steps. Table 1.
Vehicle suspension parameters
Notation Description Units Values
K1–K4 Front-lift, front-right, rear-right and rear-lift suspension stuffiness, respectively. N/m 20,000
k1–k4 Front-lift, front-right, rear-right and rear-lift tire stuffiness, respectively N/m 100,000
C1–C4 Front-lift, front-right, rear-right and rear-lift suspension damping, respectively N.s/m 100
c1–c2 Front-lift, Front-right, rear-right and rear-lift tire damping, respectively N.s/m 50
M Chassis mass kg 1500
m1–m2 Front-lift, front-right, rear-right and rear-lift tire mass, respectively kg 50
Jx Moment of inertia x-direction kg.m2 375
Jy Moment of inertia y-direction kg.m2 1500
l1 Distance m 1.7
l2 Distance m 2.3
b Distance m 1.8
Table 2.
Values of the optimal parameters of proportional-integral-derivative (PID) controller
rpµ riµ rdµ
13,261 3.3 1224

After the optimal parameters of the PID controller have been obtained, the input and output data should be used as a reference data to design the NF controller. Figure 10 shows the training phase of the NF controller. It consists of four NF sub-controllers, one for each suspension. Figure 10.
Training phase of the neurofuzzy controller.

The number of inputs for each NF sub-controller is two. The first input (Input 1) is the error between the vertical displacement at the corner where the NF sub-controller exists and vertical displacement is desired. The second input (Input 2) is the derivative of this error. The Gaussian function has been used for each NF sub-controller input. Input 1 has six grades: negative big (NB), negative small (NS), negative no change (NNC), positive no change (PNC), positive small (PS) and positive big (PB). Input 2 has five grades: NB, NS, zero (ZE), PS and PB. The Sugeno-type FIS has been used. The linear function has been used as the output membership function. The output of each controller is the force controller. It has six grades: NB, NS, NNC, PNC, PS and PB. The following rules have been used:
R1:IF error is NNC and errordot is ZE then force is NNC
R2:IF error is NB and errordot is NB then force is NB
R3: IF error is NS and errordot is NS then force is NS
R4: IF error is PNC and errordot is ZE then force is PNC
R5: IF error is PS and errordot is PS then force is PS
R6: IF error is NB and errordot is NB then force is NB
The selection of these rules depends on the response of the optimal PID controller.

The back-propagation error algorithm has been used to find the optimal values for each NF sub-controller. Figures 11–14 show the fuzzy rules surface viewer for each NF sub-controller. Figure 11.
Fuzzy rule surface viewer for the neurofuzzy controller at corner 1. Figure 12.
Fuzzy rule surface viewer for the neurofuzzy controller at corner 2. Figure 13.
Fuzzy rule surface viewer for the neurofuzzy controller at corner 3. Figure 14.
Fuzzy rule surface viewer for the neurofuzzy controller at corner 4.

To improve the NF controller the gain input values should be adjusted for each NF sub-controller. Figure 2 shows the NF controller with GE and GED gains. The ASR has been applied to find the optimal values of gain inputs to meet all control objectives. The optimal value of GE is equal to 13 and GED is equal to 4.165.

Equations (11)–(14) show that the vertical displacement at the center of gravity (zc); the vertical displacement at P3 (z3); the pitching movement α; and rolling movement η are dependent on the vertical displacement at P1, P2 and P4, that is, z1, z2 and z4. The suspension deflection (zi – wi) and body acceleration (z··c) are used to evaluate the road handling and riding comfort of the passengers, respectively. By supplying the control signal, it is expected that just the vertical displacements of sprung mass (zi) and body acceleration (z··c) will be targeted to be reduced, while the vertical displacements of unsprung masses (wi) are not relevant. Therefore, when zi decreases, the road handling performance will be improved, while when body acceleration decreases, the riding comfort is improved. In this paper only the responses of the vertical displacements at P1, P2 and P4 and the body acceleration have been shown for comparison. In Figures 15–17, the time responses of the full vehicle nonlinear active model without a controller (passive system), with the optimal PID controller and with the NF controller at P1, P2 and P4 are compared, respectively. Figure 18 shows the response of the body acceleration at the vehicle’s center of gravity. During the training phase, the input road profile is selected as a white noise random signal. From these figures it can be shown that the NF controller is more powerful and efficient than the optimal PID controller. Figure 15.
Time response of vertical displacement at P1. Figure 16.
Time response of vertical displacement at P2. Figure 17.
Time response of vertical displacement at P4. Figure 18.
Time response of body acceleration at Pc.

sec.title: 6. Test of robustness of the proposed controller
sec.p: The efficient controller is the controller that it is still stable even when the disturbance signal is applied on the plant. Therefore, to establish the effectiveness of any controller, the robustness should be examined. Six types of disturbances are applied in turn to check the robustness of the NF controller.

sec.title: 6.1. Square input signal with varying amplitude is applied as the road input profile
sec.p: The square input signal has been applied as the road input. The amplitude of this signal has been changed from 0.01 to 0.1 m. At each value the cost function (as described in Equation (23) has been calculated: (23)ϕ=0.5∑ɛ=1 4zɛ 2.

Figure 19 shows the response of the cost function against the amplitude of the square input. Figure 19.
Response of the cost functions against the different amplitude of square input.

sec.title: 6.2. Sine wave input signal with varying amplitude is applied as the road input profile
sec.p:
The different amplitude of sine wave input from 0.01 to 0.1 m has been applied as the road input profile. The response of the cost function for the passive system, optimal PID control and NF control are shown together in Figure 20. Figure 20.
Response of the cost functions against the different amplitude of sine wave input.

sec.title: 6.3. Square input signal with varying frequency is applied as the road input profile
sec.p:
The square input with fixed amplitude (0.03 m) has been applied as the road profile. The frequency of the input signal has been changed from 0.1 to 20 Hz. The cost function has been calculated for each value of the square input frequency. Figure 21 shows the cost function against different values of the square input frequencies. Figure 21.
Response of the cost functions against the different values of square input frequencies.

sec.title: 6.4. Square input signal with varying frequency is applied as the road input profile
sec.p:
A sine wave input with different frequencies (from 0.1 to 20 Hz) has been applied with fixed amplitude (0.03) to test the robustness of the proposed controller. Figure 22 shows the cost function against different values of the sine wave input frequencies. Figure 22.
Response of the cost functions against the different values of sine wave input frequencies.

sec.title: 6.5. Bending inertia torque (Tx) is applied as the road input profile
sec.p:
The different values of bending torque (from 1000 to 9000 Nm), in addition to the random signal, as the road profile have been applied. The cost function response is plotted as a function of Tx in Figure 23. Figure 23.
Response of the cost functions against different bending torques (Tx).

sec.title: 6.6. Breaking inertia torque (Ty) is applied as the road input profile
sec.p:
The different values of breaking torque (from 1000 to 9000 Nm), in addition to the random signal, as the road profile have been applied. The cost function response is plotted as a function of Ty in Figure 24. Figure 24.
Response of the cost functions against different braking torques (Ty).

sec.title: 7. Conclusion
sec.p: A novel NF controller has been successfully developed for a full vehicle nonlinear active suspension system. The results have been compared with the optimal PID controller and the corresponding system without a controller. The simulation results of the proposed NF controller indicate that the proposed controller enables the vertical displacement at each body suspension point to become much smaller than the responses of the corresponding PID controller or the passive system. It has been confirmed that the proposed controller is more robust than the optimal PID controller. Six different road profiles, acting as the system input, have been applied to assess the robustness of the proposed controller under disturbances. The test of the robustness proves that the NF controller is still stable and it forces the cost function to be minimum, even when significant disturbances occurred. The results have confirmed that when the NF controller has been used, the cost function is close to zero, while when the optimal PID controller is used, the cost function has a much greater value.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial or not-for-profit sectors.
